column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1.
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Due to industrial development and the improved quality of human life , the economic and social demand for energy is growing .
#Text=In recent years , the problems arising from the use of coal , petroleum , and other energy resources with high carbon content are becoming almost unbearable .
#Text=The trend of annual average of atmospheric CO2 concentration has been increasing non-stop in the last decades .
#Text=The global average surface temperature was reported to be approximately 1 °C higher than that of the preindustrial period .
#Text=The transition to an energy system that relies primarily on renewable energy sources has become one of the greatest challenges for alleviating climate change .
#Text=Clean energy sources such as wind , solar , geothermal , biomass , biofuels , waves , tidal , and hydropower can replace fossil fuels .

#Text=With that in mind , water value is due not only to its agricultural and domestic use , but also to the possibility of being a source of energy , such as hydropower , ocean energy , or the energy obtained from its distribution network , for instance .
#Text=In this context , collecting small amounts of energy from the ambient in order to supply power to wireless devices has been investigated for the last decades .
#Text=Moreover , in some cases where batteries are impractical , such as inaccessible remote systems , health monitoring , or body sensors , energy harvesting technology is very promising .
#Text=In fact , the power supply is one of the biggest challenges regarding the wireless sensor network applications .
#Text=Frequently , the lifetime is confined to a battery supply , which is awkward .
#Text=Several environmental resources that offer enough power can be studied such as vibration , solar irradiation , thermal differences , and hybrid energy sources .
#Text=Vibration energy harvesting ( VeH ) transforms mechanical energy obtained from ambient sources to electricity in order to power remote sensors .
#Text=VeH technologies have been widely studied over the past decade . Izadgoshasb et al. proposed a new double pendulum-based piezoelectric system to harvest energy from human movements .
#Text=They found a high increase in maximum output voltage in comparison to the conventional system and to an analogous system with only one pendulum .
#Text=Furthermore , they stated that the double pendulum design could be further improved by varying some design parameters regarding dimensions or material .
#Text=In a more recent work , Izadgoshasb et al. proposed a multi-resonant harvester that consists of a cantilever beam with two triangular branches .
#Text=They performed a parametric study using the finite element method ( FEM ) for the design optimization in order to get close resonances at low-frequency spectrum .

#Text=Experimental results showed that the proposed harvester can harvest broadband energy from ambient vibration sources and is better than analogous piezoelectric energy harvesters with cantilever beams .

#Text=Energy harvesting from flow-induced vibrations has also attracted attention in the past years , and energy obtained from fluid – structure interaction ( FSI ) in different fluids , air , or liquid have been investigated by Elahi et al. .
#Text=Under flow loads , a structure can suffer different effects , such as limit cycle oscillations , chaotic movements , or internal resonances .
#Text=From the point of view of aerodynamics , vortex-induced vibrations or vibrations caused by flutter or galloping can occur .
#Text=Using piezoelectric devices placed in a flow field can convert large oscillations into electrical energy .
#Text=An airfoil section placed on the end of cantilever piezoelectric beam can be used as a flutter energy harvester .
#Text=Flutter speed is a critical value , from which the aerodynamic system becomes unstable .

#Text=The self-excited oscillations that appear on the aeroelastic system once the critical value is overpassed are quite beneficial from the dynamic point of view ; see Abdelkefi et al. . Elahi et al.
#Text=modeled a nonlinear piezoelectric aeroelastic energy harvester that works on a postcritical aerolastic regime .
#Text=An analytical model was developed taking into account the fluid – structure interaction and electromechanical performance .

#Text=They concluded that higher electromechanical factor gives better harvesting . Wang et al. conducted a study on a galloping-based piezoelectric energy harvester using isosceles triangle sectioned bluff bodies and applying computational fluid dynamics ( CFD ) to simulate the aerodynamic forces .
#Text=They performed a parametric study in order to get the optimum vertex angle of the triangle and provided a guideline for efficient design .

#Text=They determined that an angle of 130 degrees was the most adequate within the specific electromechanical coupling of their prototype . Dai et al. investigated energy harvesting obtained from wind flow-induced vibrations .

#Text=They compared experimentally four different test cases of piezoelectric energy harvesters , and based on the results they concluded which was the best orientation of the bluff body to design efficient devices . Jia et al. presented an upright piezoelectric energy harvester ( UPEH ) that has a cylinder extension along its length .
#Text=In the case with low speed wind , energy is obtained by vortex-induced vibrations ( VIVs ) that produce bending deformation .

#Text=The UPEH can generate energy from low-speed wind by bending deformation produced by vortex-induced vibrations ( VIVs ) . Zulueta et al. developed a new control law for a contactless piezoelectric wind energy harvester , and afterwards , Bouzelata et al. improved this wind energy harvester as a battery charger
#Text=The simulation results proved that the device could power the battery when the wind speed is v = 2.7 m/s , taking into account that usually the moderate wind speed is considered to be 4 m/s .
